lessons.name: Congratulations and Welcome
lessons.description: Congratulations and Welcome to the Footwork Fastlane! You're about to build your footwork from the ground up, and I'll be there to guide you every step of the way.

lessons.name: You Can Do It
lessons.description: Everyone has excuses. The difference between the best badminton players vs average ones is simple: they don't let their excuses stop them. You will be successful as long as you put in the work.

lessons.name: The Five Footwork Functions
lessons.description: Everyone wants to have good footwork, but what exactly does that mean? These five functions define how effective a player's footwork is.

lessons.name: Muscle Memory
lessons.description: How are the world's top performers able to be so...excellent? It all comes down a deceptively simple concept called muscle memory.

lessons.name: Building Blocks of Footwork
lessons.description: The 8 building blocks are the individual elements needed to build beautiful footwork. A player must master all 8 to technical precision before they can become proficient.

lessons.name: Stance
lessons.description: Building block number 1. A player's stance is the way they position themself before moving to the shuttle. Since everything flows from the stance, an optimised stance affects all aspects of footwork.

lessons.name: Split Step
lessons.description: Building block number 3. The split step first slips by unnoticed, but is a crucial element of badminton footwork. It enables fast, explosive movements from the base position as well as a momentum "reset". A secret ingredient for sure.

lessons.name: Running and Chasse Steps
lessons.description: Building block 3 and 4. Running steps and chasse steps are both ways of travelling around the court. They both have unique pros and cons, so a skilled badminton player must be able to select the correct option based on the situation.

lessons.name: Lunge
lessons.description: Building block number 5. The lunge is a large, final step used to cover extra distance - commonly used at the front of the court. Be sure to complete the assignments in below.

lessons.name: Scissor Kick
lessons.description: The 6th building block. The scissor kick is used at the back of the court when playing overhead shots. It allows the player to generate extra momentum and sets up for an aggressive recovery.

lessons.name: China Jump
lessons.description: The 7th building block. The China jump is also used at the back of the court for overhead shots. Though it isn't as powerful as the scissor kick due to the lack of body rotation, it's a more versatile option.

lessons.name: Net Jump
lessons.description: The final building block. The net jump is used to pounce on a loose shot at the net. High risk, high reward.

lessons.name: Putting it all Together
lessons.description: You learnt a lot this module - let's recap.

lessons.name: Module 3 Intro
lessons.description: Welcome to Module 3. This is where things start to get juicy as you start to combine the 8 building blocks and move around a badminton court. You’re going to learn a lot in this module, so make sure you work at a pace you’re comfortable with and take in all the information.

lessons.name: Front Court
lessons.description: We’ll kick this module off with the front court.

lessons.name: Forehand Front Court
lessons.description: In this lesson, you’ll learn about the three main ways of moving to the forehand front corner: Runnings steps, chasse steps and the net jump - as well as the best option to select based on the situation. Finally, we’ll talk about recovery from this corner and why there’s another two different options.

lessons.name: Backhand Front Court
lessons.description: The backhand front court is next. Although a lot of this is similar to the forehand corner, there are a few differences you need to learn. Again we’ll cover all the movement options, recovery options, and how to choose between them

lessons.name: Rear Court
lessons.description: With the front court complete, let’s move on to the rear court.

lessons.name: Forehand Rear Court
lessons.description: The forehand rear corner is a critically important corner in badminton. In this lesson you’ll learn more about the scissor kick, China jump and step out to this corner. As well as the “secret” that allows you to move to this corner with more efficiency.

lessons.name: Backhand Rear Court
lessons.description: Everyone struggles with backhand shots, but if you’re able to move to this corner well you can turn a weakness into a strong overhead shot. The movement to this corner is actually pretty different to the forehand corner, so pay close attention.

lessons.name: Smash Defense
lessons.description: With the front and rear court completel, the mid court is next. Defending smashes comes down to a split second. Learn the best way to move to increase your chance of staying in the rally.

lessons.name: Interceptions
lessons.description: Pulling off a successful counter attack with an interception is one of the most satisfying things in badminton. Learn how to cut off your opponents flat lifts and change the pace of the rally.

lessons.name: The Importance of Drills
lessons.description: Congratulations and Welcome to the Footwork Fastlane! You're about to build your footwork from the ground up, and I'll be there to guide you every step of the way.

lessons.name: Shadow Drills
lessons.description: Everyone has excuses. The difference between the best badminton players vs average ones is simple: they don't let their excuses stop them. You will be successful as long as you put in the work.

lessons.name: Multifeed Drills
lessons.description: Everyone wants to have good footwork, but what exactly does that mean? These five functions define how effective a player's footwork is.

lessons.name: Live Rallies
lessons.description: How are the world's top performers able to be so...excellent? It all comes down a deceptively simple concept called muscle memory.

lessons.name: Conclusion
lessons.description: How are the world's top performers able to be so...excellent? It all comes down a deceptively simple concept called muscle memory.

lessons.name: Diving Masterclass
lessons.description: We all dream of pulling off the perfect dive, recovering, then winning the rally. In this bonus lesson, former England International player Ben Beckman will teach you exactly how to do that.

lessons.name: Mobility Manual
lessons.description: Welcome to the Mobility Manual! This will help you develop the lower body mobility needed to get into the correct positions for efficient footwork.

lessons.name: Jeremy
lessons.description: Welcome to the Student Analysis bonus course! Here, I will be doing a breakdown/analysis of several Footwork Fastlane student's movement. There should be something for everyone to learn here.

lessons.name: Introduction
lessons.description: Welcome to the Explosive Strength bonus course, where you’ll build the lower body strength to supplement your new found footwork skills.

lessons.name: Key Principles of Strength Training
lessons.description: Strength training can be a beast, before you start it’s important that you understand these key principles.

lessons.name: Exercises
lessons.description: Time to dive in to the meat and potatoes, the actual exercises themselves. Learn how to do these 4 lower body exercises properly, and implement them into your routine.

lessons.name: Program
lessons.description: A solid training program is key to achieving true results. Here’s yours. Note: Please make sure you're able to preform all the exercises safely and with good form before you start adding weights
